borough: London Borough of Barking and Dagenham
decision_conditions: <p>The proposal, by reason of&nbsp;siting and scale, would be an undesirable addition which would cause unacceptable overshadowing, loss of privacy&nbsp;and an overbearing impact to neighbouring dwellings. This would result in a harmful impact to the amenity currently enjoyed by neighbouring occupiers. As such, it fails to protect residential amenity and constitutes un-neighbourly development. The proposal thus fails to accord with the following policies which seek to ensure that development proposals protect residential amenity:</p><ul type="disc"><li>Paragraph 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework&nbsp;National Planning Policy Framework (NPPF) (DLUHC, 2021)</li><li>Policy D6 of the London Plan (March 2021)</li><li>Policies&nbsp;BP8 and BP11 of the&nbsp;Local Development Framework (LDF) Borough Wide Development Plan Document (DPD) (March 2011)</li><li>Sections 4.2&nbsp;and 5.3 of the Residential Extensions and Alterations Supplementary Planning Document (February 2012)</li><li>Policies DMD1 and DMD6 of&nbsp;The London Borough of Barking and Dagenham’s Draft Local Plan: (Regulation 19 Submission Version, December 2021)</li></ul>

<p>The proposal, by reason of siting, design, scale and bulk, would be an undesirable addition which would not appear subservient to the original dwelling, would unbalance the symmetry across the&nbsp;terrace row and&nbsp;entrance to Amidas Gardens,&nbsp;would close off the openness of the corner plot and&nbsp;would disrupt the built form of a banjo cul-de-sac. As a result, it fails to respect or reflect the character of the original dwelling, terrace row and surrounding area, and&nbsp;fails to respect, preserve or enhance the local distinctiveness of the Becontree Estate.&nbsp;It would have a harmful impact on each of these, as well as on the street scene along Marlborough Road and Amidas Gardens.&nbsp;The proposal is thus contrary to the following policies which seek to ensure that development is of a high quality, has regard to local character and appearance and is sympathetic to the historic character:</p><ul type="disc"><li>Paragraph 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework&nbsp;National Planning Policy Framework (NPPF) (DLUHC, 2021)</li><li>Policy D1, D4 and HC1 of the London Plan (March 2021)</li><li>Policies CP2 and CP3 of the&nbsp;Local Development Framework (LDF) Core Strategy (July 2010)</li><li>Policies BP2, BP8 and BP11 of the&nbsp;Local Development Framework (LDF) Borough Wide Development Plan Document (DPD) (March 2011)</li><li>Sections 4.1 and 5.4 of the Residential Extensions and Alterations Supplementary Planning Document (February 2012)</li><li>Policies SP2, DMD4&nbsp;and DMD6 of&nbsp;The London Borough of Barking and Dagenham’s Draft Local Plan: (Regulation 19 Submission Version, December 2021)</li></ul>
